alert.note: Alert for Cabarrus (North Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Greenville-Spartanburg (Western North Carolina and Northwest South Carolina)
info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued June 20 at 4:04PM EDT until June 20 at 10:00PM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: The National Weather Service in Greenville-Spartanburg has issued a * Flash Flood Warning for... Cabarrus County in the piedmont of North Carolina... * Until 1000 PM EDT. * At 404 PM EDT, Emergency management is reporting flooded roadways near the Rowan-Cabarrus County line in Kannapolis. 1-2 inches of rain quickly fell over the past 1-2 hours on top of 2-4 inches of rainfall which occurred last night. Saturated soils and high stream flows are responding quickly to this additional excessive runoff. * Lake Kannapolis Dam is spilling significant flows into Irish Buffalo Creek and these flows are likely to cause or are already causing flooding of points downstream including C Street, Pump Station Rd, Tiffany Drive, Pine Street, and Rainbow Drive. * Exercise extreme caution when traveling in the Kannapolis area. Avoid all flooded roadways and obey all barricades. Stay away from all streams, but especially Irish Buffalo Creek. Significant flows will sweep away cars and persons caught in the flood waters. HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing flash flooding. SOURCE...Emergency management reported. IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses. High flow going over Kannapolis Dam will cause downstream flooding along Irish Buffalo Creek, impacting roads, low-lying areas, and possibly several low-lying structures. * Some locations that are experiencing flash flooding include... Kannapolis, Downtown Concord, West Concord, Harrisburg, Enochville, and Mt Pleasant. FLASH FLOOD...OBSERVED FLASH FLOOD DAMAGE THREAT...CONSIDERABLE
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles.
